description: On March 27, 2020, it was announced that the dissemination of false information regarding coronavirus provides for criminal liability within the framework of the law in Kyrgyzstan. Distributors of fake messages related to the situation around the coronavirus in Kyrgyzstan have been detained, the press service of the State Committee for National Security said. On March 26, employees of the department detained a 56-year-old resident of Batken region, who disseminated false information about the situation with COVID-19 in the region. The second detainee, a 36-year-old resident of the At-Bashi district of the Naryn region, claimed that at the sanitary post in the village of Kochkor of the district of the same name, police officers did not check documents and demanded 200 soms for travel. "Preventive conversations were held with these persons, they repented of their deeds and asked forgiveness from the people. At present, measures are being taken to give a legal assessment of their actions," the State Committee for National Security said in a statement. Note that the department, together with law enforcement agencies, continue to work to identify individuals who spread rumors and fake information. Such cases bear criminal liability.

description: On 27 May 2020, The Ministry of Health urged Kyrgyzstanis not to self-medicate for COVID. Deputy Minister of Health of the Kyrgyz Republic Nurbolot Usenbayev called on citizens not to self-medicate from coronavirus infection. "During the analysis, it turned out that people practiced self-medication, including doctors. This is unacceptable, given the insidiousness of the virus. You cannot self-medicate, take low-quality medications, tinctures and follow unproven recommendations. We have said before that even with the flu, self-medication can lead to complications, "Usenbaev said. He urged everyone to seek medical help at the first symptoms of COVID-19.

description: Starting on April 6, 2020, potential coronavirus-infected Bishkek residents will be able to identify by phone. (Kyrgyzstan) Now Bishkek residents can get prompt medical advice on self-diagnosis by calling the hotline of the Ministry of Health 118. Physicians will collect an epidemiological history directly by phone, find out the details of the caller's well-being and fill out a questionnaire developed by specialists. The mayor's office asks residents to call if they: arrived from other countries within the last 30 days; visited epidemically disadvantaged regions of the country; have had close contact with an infected COVID-19; were at observation points or in-home quarantine under the supervision of doctors; have the following symptoms: fever, cough, shortness of breath. "If there is a threat of detecting an infection, mobile teams of doctors will go to the scene: a doctor, an epidemiologist and a laboratory assistant, they will do an express screening right at home. According to the results of an express test, the patient will be isolated at home until the results of the PCR analysis in a virological laboratory.Law enforcement agencies will ensure safety ". The self-test line runs from 8 am to 7 pm. A mobile application has also been developed to record the movements of citizens in quarantine with a daily questionnaire on the state of health. Every citizen in quarantine is now under SMART control.

description:
On 29 May 2020, The infectious disease center in Bishkek is overcrowded - the reception of patients has been temporarily stopped. (Kyrgyzstan) Only seriously ill patients with coronavirus will be admitted to the Republican Clinical Infectious Diseases Hospital, Chief Physician Gulzhigit Aaliev said. He explained that the restriction on admission is temporary and is due to the fact that the clinic is already overcrowded. "Today, 180 patients with coronavirus are in the hospital. Another reason was that we detected an infection in 19 employees. We will not accept new patients yet, except for those who are admitted in serious condition. Such patients will be placed in the intensive care unit," said Aaliev. According to him, most patients will be discharged from the medical facility within 14 days.
After that, the Republican Hospital will be gradually closed for observation. All employees will be tested again, and the hospital will be disinfected." He noted that the medical staff did not leave the clinic for more than two months. While the step-by-step disinfection is carried out, employees will be able to rest.

description: On 29 June 2020, Jeenbekov signed a law on the status of health workers. (Kyrgyzstan) The law prescribes what guarantees and compensation can be received by medical workers of state institutions during emergency and emergency situations. At the same time, in certain circumstances, employees of private clinics can count on these guarantees. President Sooronbai Jeenbekov signed a document amending the Law "On the status of a medical worker", the press service of the head of the Kyrgyz Republic reports. The law was adopted by the Jogorku Kenesh on May 21, 2020. "This law was adopted in order to establish guarantees and compensations for medical workers of state and municipal health organizations, including in cases of introduction of an emergency or state of emergency," the message says. In particular, Article 11-1 appeared. It is about the fact that in an emergency or emergency, the authorized body in the field of health is obliged to: organize transport delivery of medical workers of state and municipal health organizations from their place of residence to their place of work and back; provide medical workers with the necessary personal protective equipment and proper working conditions. This article also provides for the payment of monetary compensation to health workers who are at high risk of harm to their health during the period of emergency and emergency situations. It is determined by the government, but not less than four salaries for the position held.
type_text: A decree specifies the new status of medical workers, institutionalizing all the compensation and privileges, also acknowledging all the risks that they have been exposed to..

description: Starting at Jan 10, Kyrgyzstan, at border points with China, tightened medical control so as not to miss a new type of pneumonia, Abdykadyr Zhoroev, head of the epidemiological department of the Department of Disease Prevention and State Sanitary and Epidemiological Surveillance of the Ministry of Health, said that they receive information from the Chinese side through the World Health Organization. According to him, control has been strengthened at the checkpoints on the border with China: Torugart and Irkeshtam, as well as at the Manas airport, as flights from Urumqi arrive daily. In particular, Kyrgyz doctors use thermal imagers. "If there are first signs, including fever, that is, an increase in temperature, then thermal imagers will" catch "them. If a patient is identified, he will be isolated and treated in medical institutions. To date, no such patients have been identified," Zhoroev said. He noted that not only citizens of Kyrgyzstan, but also of China are checked at sanitary control points. That is, even if the patient is able to cross the border when contacting doctors with primary signs (fever and shortness of breath), the latter will immediately inform the Ministry of Health about him. Moreover, it does not matter whether patients will apply to private or state clinics, doctors are obliged to warn the department.

description: Starting on Jan 26, the government of Kyrgyzstan has strengthened security measures at airports, at the borders; it is planned to create checkpoints on the border with Kazakhstan. Specialists of the sanitary and quarantine point (SQP) check with thermal imagers all persons arriving in Kyrgyzstan from China and third countries. 11 sanitary and quarantine points operate around the clock. They are installed on the borders with China, Tajikistan, and Uzbekistan. Now the issue of creating sanitary and quarantine points on the internal borders of the EAEU (Kyrgyzstan - Kazakhstan) is being resolved since with the entry into the EAEU such points were disbanded. Starting next week, temporary sanitary and quarantine posts will start working at the Akzhol, Dunlarov Bridge, Aktilek, and Chaldovar checkpoints. Round-the-clock control over flights from other countries is organized. Doctors carry out thermometry at the exit from the aircraft. Four portable thermal imagers are operational, the isolator is prepared.

(Kyrgyzstan) 56 Kyrgyz citizens who arrived from Sol-Iletsk and two more drivers who are under observation in the Talas region will stay there for another week, said the coordinator of the Ministry of Health for the region Aizhamal Shambetova. According to her, such a decision was made by the regional headquarters, since in other regions coronavirus is detected among those arriving from Sol-Iletsk. "Prior to that, citizens were placed on observation in Talas region for five days. Their tests were taken, they are negative. They took a PCR test again and will be sent home a week later. "In addition, the members of the headquarters recommended that citizens, as far as possible, avoid crowded places, limit events with the participation of a large number of people, strictly observe the rules of personal hygiene, and conduct explanatory work with children," the statement said.

description: On March 5, "a court in Kyrgyzstan...banned mass rallies in the centre of the capital until July."
Kyrgyzstan on March 6, canceled "all the theatrical performances and concerts."
In Kyrgyzstan "All cultural and sports events with participation of more than 100 people are canceled in Bishkek," as of March 11.
Kyrgyzstan "government officially introduced a temporary ban on holding mass cultural, sports and other events" as ruled on March 12.

Starting on Mar 12, 2020, the government has officially limited the holding of mass events in the Kyrgyz Republic. According to the order, government agencies must carry out certain procedures. There are recommendations for those who work in the areas of trade, catering and services. The government of Kyrgyzstan has officially introduced a temporary restriction on holding mass events until the epidemiological situation in the world improves, the press service of the head of state said. The corresponding order was signed by Prime Minister Mukhammedkaly Abylgaziev. The decision was made in order to prevent the coronavirus COVID-19 and ensure the sanitary and epidemiological well-being of the population. Individuals and legal entities who work in the areas of trade, services and catering are advised to refrain from holding and participating in public events until the time limit is lifted, as well as to install sanitizers and indoor air purifiers, and provide employees and visitors with disinfectants. Ministries, state committees, administrative departments, plenipotentiaries of the government in the regions, state administrations and local governments were instructed to take measures to provide institutions providing state and municipal services to the population with disinfectants, as well as to carry out explanatory work.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On March 9 2020, it was announced that in Kyrgyzstan, events at Nooruz were canceled due to the threat of coronavirus. All cultural events that were planned for the near future were canceled throughout the country. Festive events on the occasion of Nooruz, the Day of the Spring Equinox, have been canceled in Kyrgyzstan, the press service of the government told Sputnik Kyrgyzstan. On March 21, there will be no traditional walks around the country and concert programs. This is due to measures to prevent coronavirus in the country. The traditional equestrian games at Nooruz have also been canceled.
Earlier, the government said that mass cultural events planned for the near future had been canceled throughout Kyrgyzstan. This decision was made by the Republican Headquarters for the implementation of economic measures aimed at minimizing the consequences of external shocks, including in connection with the spread of coronavirus, on the recommendation of the Ministry of Health of the Kyrgyz Republic.

description: On March 21st, 2020, with the introduction of an emergency regime, movement from one city to another will be limited, said First Deputy Prime Minister Kubatbek Boronov. He asked to treat with understanding the actions of the authorities. "When a quarantine is introduced, citizens will be restricted in movement. In other countries, the spread of the virus is stopped by reducing contacts. Therefore, the population should be at home. But there will be no obstacles to economic activity," Boronov said. Checkpoints will be set up at the entrance to the Issyk-Kul region. At the same time, there will be no restrictions if you need to get to another city for an important reason. Press Secretary of the Ministry of Transport and Roads Kylych Dosumbetov said that the Bishkek-Osh highway and other inter-regional routes will not be closed. On March 22, Only special vehicles - garbage collection, cash collectors - and vehicles for freight and transit transportation, delivery of food, consumer goods, medicines and basic necessities will be able to pass freely through the checkpoints between settlements. All special cases are considered by the headquarters of local self-government bodies on an individual basis. The press service said that when crossing a checkpoint, an ID document is required. Passengers of cars crossing checkpoints should have a document with them. It is enough for a person driving to show a driver's license," the press service said. UPDATE: The original policy on March 21st did not specify who is allowed to not comply with internal restriction of movement. On March 22nd, 2020, it was announced which institutions were allowed to resume their work.

On May 6, when entering Issyk-Kul, authorities will not require a health certificate. The authorities of the Issyk-Kul region decided not to require a certificate from visitors about the coronavirus test. Citizens entering the Issyk-Kul region will be sent to a 14-day home quarantine, the press service of the government's plenipotentiary office in the region reported. This decision was made at a meeting of the regional operational headquarters. "Now, those entering the region will not require a certificate of negative test results for COVID-19, but they will be sent to a 14-day home quarantine at the place of arrival," the embassy said. UPDATE: The original policy prohibited movement between the cities. On 6 May 2020, authorities have allowed entrance to Issyk Kul without requiring any health certificates but making 14 days quarantine mandatory.

description: On April 23 in Kyrgyzstan the holding of mass iftars in "in mosques, in cafes and at homes" will not be possible this year.

On 27 April 2020, Osh has banned the 10th and 20th anniversary of graduates and school celebrations, that were supposed to take place in May. (Kyrgyzstan) The commandant said that all planned school celebrations are prohibited and students will take exams remotely. Due to quarantine, all festive events are prohibited in schools in the Osh region, said the commandant of Osh, Nookat and Kara-Suu districts Malik Nurdinov. For example, according to him, the 10-year and 20-year anniversaries of graduates will be banned. Nurdinov advised to give gifts at school without big celebrations or to present them next year. Also, the commandant said that schoolchildren will take exams remotely and therefore proms are also banned.

description: On 29 April 2020, Deputy Prime Minister announced that transition exams in schools will be held remotely. (Kyrgyzstan) The fourth quarter in educational institutions of Kyrgyzstan is held remotely, Aida Ismailova recalled. Distance learning in schools in Kyrgyzstan will last until the end of the academic year, Deputy Prime Minister Aida Ismailova said at a briefing. She recalled that in the fourth quarter of all schoolchildren were transferred to distance learning. "It will last until the end of the academic year. All transfer exams will also be held remotely," Ismailova said.

description: On 10 May 2020, Boronov announced that Iftars will be banned during the quarantine. The first deputy head of government promised that local authorities will check food outlets for compliance with the quarantine regime. Iftars (breaking the fast) during Orozo will also be prohibited during the quarantine regime, First Deputy Prime Minister Kubatbek Boronov said. According to Boronov, if a cafe or teahouse where Muslims spend their evening fasting is found, the leadership will be fined a large sum. Orozo will end on May 22 or 23, depending on the appearance of the moon.

description: On 21 May 2020, it was announced by muftiat that Ait-namaz on the square and in mosques of Kyrgyzstan will not be held. On the holiday, the KTRK will broadcast congratulations and an appeal to Muslims from the Supreme Mufti of Kyrgyzstan. There will be no ait namaz in squares and in mosques due to the situation with the coronavirus, the press service of the Spiritual Directorate of Muslims of Kyrgyzstan said. Orozo Ait on the occasion of the completion of the holy month of Ramadan this year is celebrated on May 24, Sunday. The muftiate said that such a decision was made to prevent a mass gathering of people and the spread of coronavirus. Mufti of Kyrgyzstan Maksat Toktomushev called on Muslims to celebrate Orozo Ait at home. On May 24, from 7:00 to 7:30, KTRK will broadcast the congratulations and appeal of the mufti.

description: On 12 May 2020, it was announced that there will be no "last calls" at schools of the Kyrgyz Republic - the Ministry of Education and Science is preparing an order. To prevent them from being carried out, local authorities must carry out explanatory work. No last calls will be made for school graduates, the press service of the Ministry of Education and Science told. As noted in the department, the decision was made in accordance with the government's ban on holding mass events due to the spread of coronavirus in the country. "In general, the ministry does not allow school graduates to hold any events or graduation parties," the Ministry of Education and Science noted. Note that the school year in schools will end not on May 25, but on the 30th. The decision was made so that students have time to fully master the curriculum.

description: On March 30, Kyrgyzstan urged people to self-isolate and to go out of their homes as little as possible.

On 11 May 2020, the Mayor of Bishkek announced a fine for refusing to wear masks can go up to 5 thousand soms. According to Surakmatov, today there are penalties for violation of the quarantine regime and sanitary rules. The latest amendments to the laws were adopted on April 3, the sanctions were toughened, and now the fines can range from one thousand to 180 thousand soms. Depending on the severity of the act (violation, misconduct, crime), fines can be imposed by doctors, sanitary doctors and police. "Special attention will be paid to violation of sanitary norms, refusal to wear masks. The fine for this is from one thousand to five thousand soms," the mayor said.
